feed.title: Combined summary - Merkle trees and mountain ranges

entry.title: Combined summary - Merkle trees and mountain ranges
entry.summary: In various email exchanges and discussions on the Bitcoin development mailing list, several proposals were made regarding commitments to unspent transaction outputs (UTXO) and spent transaction outputs (STXO) in the blockchain. Peter Todd proposed the use of Merkle Mountain Ranges (MMR) for UTXO commitments, while Bram Cohen suggested using a Patricia trie data structure. Additionally, they discussed the optimization of memory usage and the security issues related to variable sized commitments.The conversations touched upon the difficulties of maintaining performance of cache misses when dealing with increasingly large UTXO/STXO/TXO sets. There were also discussions about the possibility of introducing incentives for collecting dust, concerns about introducing STXO set commitments that grow without bound, and the differences between Peter's MMR codebase and patricia trie. The proposed solutions include trailing UTXO commitments by a fixed amount to prevent latency from becoming an issue, generating proofs of inclusion and exclusion using UTXO sets efficiently without requiring a complete STXO set, and implementing a bunch of subtle implementation details to keep cache coherence down to get the number of cache misses per transaction down under one. The authors believe their underlying Merkle tree is unambiguously superior in every way and suggest porting it to C and optimizing it.Overall, the discussions focused on improving the efficiency and security of transactions within the blockchain, and finding ways to handle the challenges associated with increasing data sets.In the Bitcoin-dev mailing list conversation between Bram Cohen and Peter Todd, they discuss various proposals for UTXO and STXO commitments in Bitcoin blocks. While they agree that UTXO commitments are necessary, there is disagreement on the inclusion of STXO commitments and the use of Merkle Mountain Ranges. Cohen suggests using trailing UTXO commitments as a way to handle latency problems and proposes a raw Merkle tree with "magic pixie dust" to address cache misses as an alternative.The Bitcoin-dev mailing list conversation between Peter Todd and an unknown individual revolves around the implementation of merbinner trees and their efficiency against attackers. They clarify that each node in a merbinner tree commits to the prefix that all keys below that level start with, not just the depth. The discussion also touches upon the optimization of memory usage.In another email exchange, there is a discussion between Peter Todd and Bram Cohen regarding the proposal of UTXO and STXO commitments. They discuss the use of a merkle tree or a patricia trie for the commitments and compare the performance of hashing functions and memory cache misses between the mountain range and straight merkle tree.Finally, the Bitcoin-dev mailing list conversation between Bram Cohen and Peter Todd revolves around the issue of handling latency problems in UTXO commitments while ensuring fast validation before block propagation. The proposed approach is to trail UTXO commitments by a fixed number of blocks (not exceeding five blocks) to keep latency from becoming an issue. However, it does not imply latency to proofs of inclusion and exclusion, which can be done by adding roots of what's added and deleted in each block. Peter Todd suggests using BLAKE2b for internal hashing due to its efficiency in omitting padding when the data is exactly one block in size. There is also a discussion about the implementation of a root branch block with nodes arranged in fixed positions and terminals having outpointers to other blocks. Bram Cohen responds to Peter Todd's proposal for Merkle Mountain Range commitments in blocks and disagrees on the inclusion of STXO commitments and the use of Merkle Mountain Ranges.
